name: Student Taught Courses (StuCo): Introduction to English Syntax
base_name: Student Taught Courses (StuCo): Introduction to English Syntax
long_desc: In this course, we will learn about the syntax of English. Syntax is the study of the rules that dictate how words combine to form sentences in language. We will discuss the syntax of English both from a historical diachronic perspective, e.g. the nowlost V2 word order of Old English and from a contemporary synchronic perspective, compare dialects spoken across various speaker communities, e.g. multiple modal constructions such as We might can go up there next Saturday. where more than one modal verb in this case might and can appear in a single sentence, used in the Southern United States the zero copula of AAVE AfricanAmerican Vernacular English, where certain forms of the copula be can be omitted in certain contexts, e.g. He an expert He is an expert, but not others, e.g. I driving to Amherst Im driving to Amherst the asterisk  denotes ungrammaticality imperatives in Belfast English, where the imperative verb can precede the subject, e.g. Read you that book You read that book, whereas only the opposite word order is permissible in Standard English You read that book We will also compare the syntactic properties of English with those of other languages.  This course also covers the basics of generative linguistics, a widely accepted framework which has been used by linguists to analyze various syntactic phenomena. We will see that many interesting questions can be formulated and studied from a generative linguistic standpoint. We will also touch upon the basics of formal semantics and pragmatics and the socalled syntaxsemantics interface and the syntaxpragmatics interface, i.e. the study of how syntax interacts with semantics and pragmatics. Examples of this are quantifier raising QR and presupposition holes.

custom_fields.goals: Students will understand basic concepts of syntax, Government and Binding Theory GB, Minimalism. Students will also have a general understanding of the motivations of the theoretical transition from GB to Minimalism. Students will be able to analyze syntactic phenomena in English in terms of syntactic frameworks and theories.
custom_fields.key_topics: Chomskyan generative syntax, Government and Binding Theory, Minimalism, syntax, syntactic phenomena in English, syntax-semantics interface
custom_fields.prerequisite_knowledge: Nothing in particular, but any previous experience with languages or linguistics will help.
custom_fields.assessment_structure:
There are in-class quizzes that test student understanding of concepts discussed in class.

There is no midterm but there is a final: a group presentation. Students will form groups and present a topic of their choice at the end of the semester. Students may either 1) discuss linguistic phenomena that motivated a particular theoretical proposal, or 2) discuss a particular linguistic phenomenon in English and provide their own explanation for it.

Student participation is expected in class. Students are encouraged to ask questions and discuss with other students.

The final grade will be 30% participation, 30% quizzes (counting in the midterm quiz) and 40% presentation. To pass the class, one must obtain a minimum final grade of 60%.
custom_fields.relevance: This course is targeted to students who are interested in theoretical linguistics and is either a native or fluent speaker of English. The course is entirely focused on theoretical linguistics, in particular syntax, the study of the structure of linguistic expressions. We base most of our discussions and theories around phenomena in English, which should be accessible to all students.
custom_fields.learning_resources: There is no textbook per se, but we will read a lot of papers and book chapters, which will be announced and distributed during the semester.
custom_fields.extra_time_commitment: Students may receive reading assignments which must be completed before class. Given that we meet only once a week, the readings should take at most 2~3 hours per week on average.
